questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds to: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Globin part of Hb

 

2,3-BPG binds to the globin part of hemoglobin. The binding of 2,3-BPG reduces the oxygen affinity of hemoglobin, promoting the release of oxygen in tissues where it is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This option is not accurate. 2,3-BPG does not directly bind to the heme group of hemoglobin. Instead, it interacts with the globin chains of hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Haem part of Myoglobin:

  • This option is not accurate. Myoglobin is a single-chain protein, and it does not contain heme groups like hemoglobin. Myoglobin directly binds oxygen to store it in muscle tissues, but it does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Option D. Globin part of Myoglobin:

  • This option is not accurate. Myoglobin is a single-chain protein, and it does not contain globin chains like hemoglobin. Myoglobin directly binds oxygen in muscle tissues but does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3 BPG has negative charge whereas beta chain of hemoglobin has large positive charges due to amino acids His and Lys. Together they form the salt bridges (see fig) which promote formation of taut conformation and helps in deoxygenation.

choices.text: Herpes-simplex virus

questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes-simplex virus

 

Infection with the Herpes simplex virus (HS) causes punched-out ulcers in the esophagus.

 

Immunocompromised patients are more likely to develop HS esophagitis.

 

Endoscopic findings may include multiple discrete or coalescent small ulcers that appear superficial, punched out, or volcano-like.

 

 

For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are seen here:

 

  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Ground-glass changes in nuclei
  • Infected squamous epithelial cells show 3 M’s:
    • Molding of nuclear contours
    • Margination of chromatin to the periphery of nuclei
    • Multinucleation
  • Intranuclear inclusions:
    • Cowdry type A: acidophilic inclusion with surrounding clear halo
    • Equivocal cases require an HSV immunohistochemical (IHC) stain to confirm the diagnosis

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Causes larger, shallow ulcers and might involve deeper tissue layers, with "owl's eye" inclusions typically seen.

 

Option C. Candida: Presents typically as white plaques or linear fissures rather than punched-out ulcers.

 

Option D. Acid: Causes erosive esophagitis with continuous areas of inflammation rather than discrete ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus causes distinctive punched-out ulcers in the esophagus, particularly noted in immunocompromised patients, diagnosed by endoscopic appearance and confirmed via histopathological findings.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the CT image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PUJO (Pelviureteric Junction Obstruction)

 

The CT image shows a massively dilated renal pelvis with thinning of the renal parenchyma, which is characteristic of Pelviureteric Junction Obstruction (PUJO). In PUJO, the obstruction occurs at the junction between the renal pelvis and the ureter, causing the pelvis to become disproportionately dilated compared to the calyces. This results in significant thinning of the renal tissue, which is evident in the image. The appearance of a stretched and thin parenchyma alongside a dilated pelvis points towards PUJO.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Renal cyst: A renal cyst typically appears as a single, fluid-filled, well-defined lesion within the kidney. The key feature is that it would appear as a solitary or few non-communicating cysts, unlike the diffuse dilation and thin parenchyma seen in PUJO.

 

Option C.  AD PCKD (Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease): AD PCKD is characterized by multiple cysts throughout the kidney, which are typically non-communicating and cause the kidneys to become enlarged and lobulated. In contrast, the CT here shows a single, large, dilated pelvis rather than multiple distinct cysts.

 

Option D.  Horseshoe kidney: A horseshoe kidney is a congenital condition where the kidneys are fused at the lower poles, forming a horseshoe shape. It does not present with significant pelvis dilation or obstructive features as seen in this CT image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PUJO is characterized by massive dilation of the renal pelvis with thinning of the renal parenchyma due to obstruction at the pelviureteric junction. The pelvis is more dilated than the calyces, which is a hallmark finding on imaging.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with Graves' disease with eye signs and enlarged thyroid is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. What medication can be administered in the preoperative period to minimize intraoperative bleeding in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Potassium iodide

 

Potassium iodide, which can be given 10 days before the surgery to reduce intraoperative bleeding during total thyroidectomy. This is because iodide alone produces transient remission and may reduce vascularity, thereby marginally improving safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used to prepare the patient for surgery by inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and causing beta-adrenergic blockade. However, it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding during thyroidectomy. It is beneficial in thyroid storm.

 

Option C. Propylthiouracil: Propylthiouracil is an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid synthesis and peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. It is used to render the patient euthyroid before surgery, but it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Option D. Betamethasone: Betamethasone is a glucocorticoid that reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. However, it is not used preoperatively in thyroidectomy to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in an overactive thyroid gland, known as hyperthyroidism. In this condition, the immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing it to produce more thyroid hormone than the body needs. As a result, the thyroid gland becomes hyperactive, leading to various symptoms associated with hyperthyroidism. Graves' disease is the most prevalent cause of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A patient had features of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He became bedridden and died due to respiratory failure. Brain biopsy is likely to show which of the following? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features described (resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability) are characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

 

In Parkinson's disease, the brain biopsy is likely to show Lewy bodies. Lewy bodies are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of aggregates of alpha-synuclein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hirano bodies: Seen in Alzheimer's disease and other conditions like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

 

Option C. Guarnieri bodies: (Type B inclusion) Found in cells infected with poxvirus.

 

Option D. Negri bodies: Seen in the neurons of patients with rabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Parkinson's disease, brain biopsies typically reveal Lewy bodies, which are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of alpha-synuclein.

choices.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid twice a week
60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid once a week
60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily
60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid once a month

questions.text: What dose of iron and folic acid should an anemic pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily

 

Explanation:

 

Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, which aims to reduce the prevalence of anemia in India by 3 percentage points every year, the "6 by 6 by 6" strategy is used. This strategy targets 6 beneficiaries, includes 6 interventions, and involves 6 institutional mechanisms.

 

 

One of the interventions is iron and folic acid supplementation.

 

Anemic pregnant women in their second trimester should be given 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days, as per the guidelines of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program.

 

For pregnant women, the recommended dose is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days during pregnancy. This is provided in the form of red-colored tablets. The same dose is also given to lactating mothers for 180 days post-delivery.

 

If the woman does not respond to this dosage or is anemic, then other forms of iron supplementation, such as ferrous carboxy maltose and IV sucrose, may be considered.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A person died suddenly whose family is abroad. A preservative was used to preserve his viscera. Which of the following poisoning is seen in it? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aconite

 

The question describes a scenario of sudden death where a preservative was used to preserve the viscera. The key point here is the suspicion of poisoning leading to sudden death. Aconite is a well-known cardiac poison that can cause sudden death by affecting the heart's function. Cardiac poisons such as aconite disrupt normal cardiac activity, leading to fatal arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol: While alcohol poisoning can be fatal, it typically does not cause sudden death in the manner described. The symptoms and progression of alcohol poisoning differ significantly from those of cardiac poisons.

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning usually presents with gastrointestinal symptoms and systemic toxicity. It is less likely to cause sudden cardiac death compared to aconite.

 

Option D. Thymol: Thymol is an antiseptic and fungicide, not typically associated with poisoning that leads to sudden death. Its toxic effects do not align with the scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite is a potent cardiac poison known for causing sudden death due to its severe impact on cardiac function

 

Cardiac poisons: Mnemonic - DHONAQ

 

Digitalis, Hydrogen cyanide, Oleander, Nicotine, Aconite, and Quinine.

questions.text: Methylisothiazolinone (MI) in cosmetics is used as? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preservative

 

Methylisothiazolinone (MIT) is a preservative present in various facial cosmetics, deodorants, sunscreens, and industrial products. The frequency of contact dermatitis resulting from either Methyl-chloro-isothiazolinone/methylisothiazolinone (MCI/MIT or Kathon CG) or MIT has been on the rise.

 

 

Moreover, there have been reported cases of severe airborne and generalized dermatitis caused by exposure to MIT through recently painted walls and even from toilet cleaners.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's important to understand that Methylisothiazolinone (MI) is used as a preservative in cosmetics to prevent microbial growth, distinguishing it from surfactants, humectants, and emulsifiers, which have different functional roles in product formulation.

 

Ref:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 128, Page no 128.36

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4689087/

choices.text: Lateral condyle fracture of humerus

questions.text: An 18-year-old child presents with history of fall leading to injury to the right elbow. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial head dislocation

 

RADIAL HEAD DISLOCATION

 

  • Isolated radial head dislocation is uncommon. 
  • It most commonly presents as a partial dislocation or subluxation, also known as nursemaid’s elbow, seen in children.
  • Complete radial head dislocation, although rare, is most commonly associated with high-force injuries of the arm in children as well as in adults and, therefore, is often associated with a forearm fracture or dislocation.
  • The peak incidence is between 4-10 years of age. 
  • Causes:
    • The annular ligament stabilizes the radial head.
    • In the case of subluxation, an axial force on an extended, pronated forearm causes the annular ligament to slip over the radial head.
    • A complete radial head dislocation is most commonly from a high-force injury causing a tear in the annular ligament.
    • Less often, the annular ligament remains intact, connected to the lateral collateral ligament and the ulna, causing the radial head to slip under the annular ligament.
  • On physical examination, the child with a partial displacement protectively holds their arm in an extended and pronated fashion.
  • There is discomfort and pain over the radial head, and the child refuses to use arm by holding it close to body.
  • The patient also resists forearm range of motion testing.
  • A lateral view x-ray of the elbow shows the “ulnar bow sign” seen in isolated radial head dislocation.
  • There is a slight curvature in the ulna on the lateral view.
  • "Isolated" dislocation of the radial head is almost always in fact associated with a bowing fracture of the ulna.

 

Ulnar bow sign

 

  • The lateral humeral line (LHL) is often used to diagnose lateral radial head dislocation on the anterior-posterior x-ray.
  • The LHL is a line drawn along the lateral edge of the lateral condyle parallel to the axis of the distal shaft of the humerus.
  • It typically intersects the lateral cortex of the radial neck.

 

Lateral humeral line

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow dislocation: The most common dislocation is posterior or posterolateral and is usually the result of a fall with forearm supinated and the elbow either extended or partially flexed. Simple dislocations result in injuries of the medial and lateral collateral ligament complexes without bony injury. Complex dislocations are associated with fractures about the elbow. Associated soft tissue injuries may involve the brachial artery, ulnar nerve (most commonly), median and radial nerve. Most common joint to dislocate in children (male children in 10-15 years of age group). Most prominent part is olecranon in dislocated elbow. Symptoms include painful and swollen elbow with elbow motion painful and restricted. On physical examination, the elbow is held in flexion, and forearm appears to be shortened from the anterior and posterior view. On palpation, distal humerus creates a fullness within the antecubital fossa. Radiograph shows loss of radiocapitellar and ulnohumeral relationship but maintained radial and ulnar relationship.

 

 

Option C. Supracondylar fracture of humerus: Supracondylar humeral fractures in children are most common elbow injuries, especially in children aged 5–8 years. It occurs after a fall on an outstretched hand.

 

The child complains of pain and refusal to move the elbow. On physical examination, there is a gross deformity, swelling, ecchymosis in antecubital fossa, limited active elbow motion.

 

 

Option D. Lateral condyle fracture of humerus: This is a transphyseal intraarticular injury usually involving immature skeleton of children and adolescent. The lateral condylar (or capitellar) epiphysis begins to ossify during the first year of life and fuses with shaft at 12–16 years. Between these ages, it may be sheared off or avulsed by forceful traction. The maximum chances of injury is between 5–15 years. They are the most common distal humeral epiphyseal fractures. Mechanism of fracture is fall on outstretched arm with varus stress that “Pulls off” (avulses) lateral condyle or Valgus force (rarely) in which radial head directly pushes off the lateral condyle. The child comes with lateral elbow pain and swelling. On physical examination, there is no obvious deformity seen. The swelling and tenderness are usually limited to the lateral side. Lateral ecchymosis implies a tear in the aponeurosis of the brachioradialis and signals an unstable fracture. There may be increased pain with resisted wrist extension/flexion. Crepitus may be felt at the fracture site.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the radial head dislocation.
  • Since it is common at the age between 4-10 years, it is the correct diagnosis of the given condition.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Auditory Cortex
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Cochlear Nucleus
  4. Lateral leminiscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Olivary complex
  7. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

 

The correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors (cochlea) and moving towards the auditory cortex, is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion: The auditory nerve fibers originate here.

 

3. Cochlear Nucleus: The auditory nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

6. Olivary complex: After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary complex.

 

4. Lateral lemniscus: From the superior olivary complex, the auditory signals travel via the lateral lemniscus.

 

5. Inferior colliculus: The lateral lemniscus projects to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

7. Medial geniculate body: The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

1. Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals reach the auditory cortex (Area 41) in the temporal lobe for processing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

AUDITORY PATHWAY

 

E Eighth nerve

 

C Cochlear nucleus

 

O Olivary complex (superior)

 

L Lateral lemniscus

 

I Inferior colliculus

 

M Medial geniculate body

 

A Auditory cortex

questions.text: In which of the following conditions prolactin level is highest?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 24 hours after delivery

 

Explanation

 

Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery.

 

This hormone is secreted by the mothers anterior pituitary gland, and its concentration in her blood rises steadily from the fifth week of pregnancy until birth of the baby, at which time it has risen to 10 to 20 times the normal nonpregnant level.

 

  • 24 Hours After Delivery: Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours after ovulation: Although hormonal changes related to the menstrual cycle do affect prolactin levels, these changes are moderate and do not typically reach the peak levels seen postpartum. The role of prolactin around ovulation is less pronounced compared to its surge after delivery, where it is critical for initiating and sustaining lactation.

 

Option C. NREM Sleep: Prolactin levels naturally rise during sleep, especially during the deeper stages of NREM sleep, due to reduced dopamine activity, which normally inhibits prolactin secretion. Despite this increase, the levels achieved during sleep are usually not as high as those observed after childbirth, where prolactin plays a direct and significant role in breastfeeding.

 

Option D. After running for 1 hour: Physical activities and stress can lead to an increase in prolactin levels as part of the body's response to physiological stress or exertion. However, these increases are generally transient and significantly lower than the sustained high levels required for lactation post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other factors which leads to high prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in the body are:

 

During sleep, the hypothalamus releases dopamine, which inhibits the secretion of jectiveprolactin. As the night progresses and sleep deepens, dopamine levels decrease, leading to a decrease in the inhibition of prolactin release. Consequently, prolactin levels rise, reaching their peak in the early morning hours.

 

Prolactinoma: The most common cause of hyperprolactinemia is a noncancerous tumour of the pituitary gland called a prolactinoma.

 

Medications: Certain medications can increase prolactin levels. These include antipsychotic (such as risperidone and haloperidol), antidepressants, anti-nausea drugs (such as metoclopramide), and some high blood pressure medications.

 

Hypothyroidism: Underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) can disrupt the normal balance of hormones in the body, including prolactin regulation.

 

Chronic Kidney Disease: Kidney dysfunction or chronic kidney disease can lead to hyperprolactinemia. Impaired kidney function affects the clearance of prolactin from the blood, leading to elevated levels.

 

Stress and Emotional Factors: Extreme stress, emotional trauma, or intense physical activity can temporarily raise prolactin levels.

 

Pregnancy and Breastfeeding: During pregnancy, prolactin levels increase to prepare the breasts for milk production. After childbirth, prolactin levels remain elevated to stimulate and maintain breastfeeding.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with left-sided hemiparesis. Damage to which part of the internal capsule leads to this presentation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior limb

 

The internal capsule is a white matter structure in the brain that contains many important tracts, including those for motor and sensory functions. Damage to specific parts of the internal capsule can result in different clinical presentations based on the fibers that are affected.

 

Posterior limb is the part of the internal capsule that carries corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, which are responsible for motor and sensory functions. Damage to the posterior limb can result in contralateral hemiparesis (weakness on the opposite side of the body). Therefore, a lesion in the posterior limb of the right internal capsule would lead to left-sided hemiparesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: This part of the internal capsule contains optic radiations, which are involved in visual processing. Damage here would lead to visual deficits rather than motor or sensory deficits.

 

Option B. Sublentiform: This part carries auditory radiations and is involved in hearing. Damage to this part would result in auditory deficits, not motor weakness.

 

Option C. Anterior limb: This part of the internal capsule contains frontopontine fibers and thalamocortical radiations, which are involved in cognitive and executive functions. Damage here might affect cognition but not typically result in hemiparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule can lead to contralateral hemiparesis due to the involvement of motor and sensory pathways.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with lower back pain and fever. She has elevated amylase levels and has experienced similar episodes in the past as well. Which type of necrosis is likely to be present? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fat necrosis

 

The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of pancreatitis, including lower back pain, fever, elevated amylase levels, and a history of chronic alcohol use. Pancreatitis is a condition where inflammation of the pancreas occurs, often due to long-term alcohol consumption.

 

In pancreatitis, the digestive enzymes, particularly lipases, are released into the pancreas and surrounding tissues, leading to the breakdown of fat cells. This enzymatic activity causes fat necrosis, a process where fatty acids combine with calcium to form chalky white areas known as saponification. This type of necrosis is characteristic of chronic pancreatitis.

 

The most common precipitating factor for an acute pancreatitis attack is cholelithiasis (gallstones). Chronic pancreatitis, on the other hand, is typically associated with a long-standing history of alcohol intake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulative necrosis: Typically occurs in ischemic conditions (except in the brain) and is not associated with the enzymatic activity seen in pancreatitis.

 

Option B. Caseous necrosis: Commonly associated with tuberculosis, it has a cheese-like appearance and is not related to pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Fibrinoid necrosis: Involves immune complex deposition in blood vessels and is seen in conditions like vasculitis and certain autoimmune diseases, not in pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fat necrosis is a hallmark of pancreatitis, particularly in the context of chronic alcohol use. It is caused by the action of pancreatic enzymes on surrounding fat tissue, leading to saponification and calcium deposition.

choices.text: Only 1 is correct.
1 & 2 are correct.
2 & 3 are correct.
1, 2 & 4 are correct.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the effects of Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. Decrease in reduced glutathione
  2. Decreased NADPH
  3. Decreased lipid peroxidation
  4. Decreased RBC membrane damage
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 & 2 are correct.

 

 

 

1. Decrease in reduced glutathione:


This statement is correct. G6PD deficiency leads to reduced levels of NADPH, which is necessary to maintain GSH in its reduced form. Without sufficient GSH, RBCs are more susceptible to oxidative damage, which can lead to hemolysis.

 

2. Decreased NADPH:


This statement is also correct. G6PD deficiency directly results in decreased production of NADPH in the pentose phosphate pathway. NADPH is necessary for the regeneration of reduced glutathione, which protects cells from oxidative stress.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Decreased lipid peroxidation:


This statement is incorrect. In fact, G6PD deficiency leads to increased oxidative stress, which can result in increased lipid peroxidation, not a decrease. Lipid peroxidation damages cell membranes, contributing to RBC hemolysis.

 

4. Decreased RBC membrane damage:


This statement is incorrect. The decreased levels of reduced glutathione and increased oxidative stress lead to more, not less, RBC membrane damage. This damage makes the RBCs more prone to hemolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency leads to decreased levels of NADPH and reduced glutathione, which are essential for protecting RBCs from oxidative damage.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1197

choices.text: Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiate delirium from dementia in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute and fluctuating onset with disturbances in consciousness and attention. Dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, has a gradual, insidious onset and is primarily a disorder of memory without loss of consciousness.

 

Delirium and dementia, though distinct syndromes, can sometimes overlap in presentation, making differentiation challenging. However, some key features can help differentiate the two:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acuity of onset and agitation: While the acuity of onset can differentiate the two, both delirium and dementia can be associated with agitation.

 

Option C. Visual hallucinations and impaired memory: Visual hallucinations are more common in delirium and some types of dementia like Lewy Body Dementia but not necessarily Alzheimer's disease. Impaired memory is a feature of dementia, primarily Alzheimer's, but can also be present in delirium.

 

Option D. Agitation and irritation: Both can be seen in either delirium or dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD complaining of unable to evert the ankle. The following deformity is seen. Which of the following gait is present?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stepping gait

 

  • The image shown in the question is of high-stepping gait, where the foot drops due to common peroneal nerve injury and while walking, the foot slaps on the ground.

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • The common peroneal nerve is one of the two major branches of the sciatic nerve.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the lateral compartment of the leg, and the deep peroneal nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.
  • These two nerves are essential in the eversion of the foot and dorsiflexion of the foot, respectively.
  • The innervation of the superficial peroneal nerve are:
    • Motor:
      • Peroneus longus
      • Peroneus brevis
    • Sensory: Anterolateral leg
  • Deep peroneal nerve innervation are:
    • Motor:
      • Tibialis anterior
      • Extensor hallucis longus
      • Extensor digitorum longus
      • Peroneus tertius
    • Sensory: First dorsal webspace
  • The nerve is most vulnerable to injury as it passes around the fibular neck.
  • The most common presentation of a common peroneal nerve injury is a weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and the classic resultant foot drop while ambulating. 
  • Foot drop can develop acutely or over days to weeks, depending on the etiology. It can also be complete or partial in severity.
  • There may also be accompanying numbness or paresthesia present along the lateral leg, dorsal foot, and/or the first toe webspace.
  • Pain may also be present in traumatic cases but is not always present.
  • A patient with weakened or paralyzed dorsiflexors may ambulate with a high steppage gait to prevent dragging of toes on the ground.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Waddling gait. Weakness of the hip girdle and upper thigh muscles, like in myopathies, leads to an instability of the pelvis on standing and walking. If the muscles extending the hip joint are affected, the posture of the hip joint becomes flexed and lumbar lordosis increases. The patients have difficulty in standing up from a sitting position. Due to weakness in the gluteus medius muscle, the hip on the side of the swinging leg drops with each step (referred to as Trendelenburg sign). The gait appears waddling. The patients frequently attempt to counteract the dropping of the hip on the swinging side by bending the trunk towards the side which is in the stance phase. This waddling gait pattern can also be caused when the origin and the insertion site of the gluteus medius muscle are closer to each other than normal, for instance due to a posttraumatic elevation of the trochanter or pseudarthrosis of the femoral neck. 

 

 

Option C. Circumduction gait. Also called as Hemiplegic gait, circumduction gait is most commonly seen in stroke. The patient stands with unilateral weakness on the affected side with arm flexed, adducted and internally rotated. Leg on the same side is in extension with plantar flexion of the foot and toes. While walking, the patient hold their arm to one side and drags the affected leg in semi-circle or circumduction due to weakness of the distal muscles (foot drop) and extensor hypertonia in the lower limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is the high stepping gait, seen in the common peroneal nerve injury. This gait is present due to foot drop or weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male is brought to OPD with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. On examination, a mass was observed on left posterior choanae as shown below. What is the management of the patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Surgical excision

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Surgical excision will be the management of the patient.

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

  • Most common benign tumor of nasopharynx.
  • Site of origin: sphenopalatine foramen.
  • It is highly vascular tumor. vessels are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat. This accounts for the severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract; also, the bleeding cannot be controlled by application of adrenaline, hence biopsy is contraindicated.

 

Extensions of JNA

 

  1. Nasal cavity causing nasal obstruction, epistaxis and nasal discharge.
  2. Paranasal sinuses. Maxillary, sphenoid and ethmoid sinuses can all be invaded.
  3. Pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa and cheek.
  4. Orbits giving rise to proptosis and frog-face deformity. It enters through the inferior orbital fissure and also destroys apex of the orbit. It can also enter the orbit through superior orbital fissure.
  5. Cranial cavity. It can extend into:
  6. Anterior cranial fossa through roof of ethmoids or cribriform plate.
  7. Middle cranial fossa through erosion of floor of middle cranial fossa or indirectly by invading the sphenoid sinus and Sella turcica. In the former case, tumor lies lateral to internal carotid artery and in the latter case medial to the artery

 

Clinical features

 

  • Adolescent male
  • Profuse spontaneous recurrent epistaxis
  • Nasal obstruction with denasal speech
  • Conductive hearing loss due to tubal block
  • Pink/purple mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features like broadening of nasal bridge, proptosis, swelling of cheek, infratemporal fossa or involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth and VIth cranial nerves will depend on the extent of tumor.

 

Investigation:

 

  1. CECT (contrast enhanced CT) - This shows Hollman miller sign or antral sign i.e., anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  2. MRI is complementary to CT scan
  3. Angiography to assess blood supply of tumor. Feeding vessels should be embolized preoperatively

 

Treatment Surgical excision is treatment of choice.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): Not suitable for JNA: Due to the tumor's high vascularity, FNAC could result in significant bleeding and is not typically used for diagnosis or treatment in cases suspected of being JNA.

 

Option B. Biopsy: Risk of severe bleeding: Similar to FNAC, a direct biopsy of JNA is contraindicated due to the risk of triggering severe hemorrhage from the tumors vascular structure.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy: Not a primary treatment: While radiotherapy can be considered in certain cases where surgical excision is incomplete or not feasible, it is not the primary treatment method for JNA. The primary approach is surgical removal, given the effectiveness of surgery in achieving control of the tumor and minimizing long-term complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected JNA, especially with the classical presentation of recurrent nosebleeds in adolescent males, prompt referral for imaging and surgical consultation is critical. Surgical excision, following detailed imaging and possibly preoperative embolization, represents the best approach to manage this condition effectively.

questions.text: Arrange the steps of the Disaster cycle in sequence. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disaster impact Response Rehabilitation Mitigation  

 

The disaster cycle outlines the sequential steps taken in response to a disaster and how communities can prepare and recover from such events. The correct sequence is:

 

  1. Disaster Impact: This is the immediate occurrence of the disaster event, such as an earthquake, flood, or hurricane, leading to direct damage and disruption.
  2. Response: Following the impact, emergency measures are taken to save lives, provide first aid, conduct search and rescue, and offer immediate relief such as food, shelter, and medical treatment.
  3. Rehabilitation: After the initial response, efforts shift to restoring essential services and helping affected communities return to normal. This involves rebuilding infrastructure, ensuring public health, and restoring social and economic activities.
  4. Mitigation: This final step involves implementing measures to reduce the severity of future disasters. This can include building stronger infrastructure, improving disaster preparedness plans, and promoting community awareness to minimize potential damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the disaster cycle is: Disaster Impact Response Rehabilitation Mitigation.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with complaints of diarrhea and foul-smelling stool. His stool microscopy did not show any ova or eggs, but there was the presence of motile 200 m larva. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The Ans.  is Strongyloides stercoralis because this organism is known for producing motile larvae rather than eggs in the stool, which aligns with the findings in this patient. Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the listed options in that it is ovoviviparous: it produces eggs that hatch into larvae inside the host. This explains why motile larvae, rather than eggs or ova, are observed in stool microscopy.

 

This characteristic is crucial for distinguishing Strongyloides from other helminths, particularly in immunocompromised patients like those with HIV, where the infection can become disseminated and more severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This organism typically shows eggs, not larvae, in stool samples. It is a type of hookworm, and its diagnostic stage involves eggs rather than motile larvae.

 

Option B. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris is diagnosed by finding eggs in the stool, not larvae. It is a large roundworm whose diagnostic stage in stool is the presence of characteristic eggs.

 

Option C. Schistosoma mansoni: Schistosoma species are identified by the presence of characteristic eggs in stool or urine, depending on the species. Motile larvae are not seen in stool samples for Schistosoma infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strongyloides stercoralis is diagnosed by the presence of motile larvae in stool, distinguishing it from other helminths that typically show eggs in stool samples.

choices.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.
There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

 

Individuals who are sleepwalking typically act without conscious awareness and usually have no memory of the episode upon awakening.

 

Other Options:

 

Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a disorder of arousal from slow-wave sleep.

 

Option A. Disorder of sleep arousal: True. Sleepwalking arises from deep, non-REM (NREM) stage 4 sleep, making it a disorder of arousal.

 

Option C. Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion: True. When sleepwalkers are awakened, they are often disoriented and confused.

 

Option D. There may be neurological conditions associated: True. While many cases of somnambulism have no clear cause, certain neurological conditions can be associated with it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep. Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as OCD as per ICD 11? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PTSD

 

The International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11), like the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), classifies a number of disorders under the umbrella of obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. However, PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder) is not classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11. Instead, it's classified under trauma- and stressor-related disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichotillomania: This is classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option B. Body dysmorphic disorder: This too is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option C. Hypochondriac disorder: Now termed "Illness Anxiety Disorder" in DSM-5, this is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders in ICD-11 are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Olfactory reference disorder
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 43-47

questions.text: A patient's relatives sent a message on social media to the consulting doctor, unaware about the other investigations. But he mentioned that urinary coproporphyrin is positive. What is the probable cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lead poisoning

 

Lead poisoning is known to interfere with the heme synthesis pathway by inhibiting key enzymes such as delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase, coproporphyrinogen oxidase, and ferrochelatase. The inhibition of coproporphyrinogen oxidase leads to an accumulation of coproporphyrin in the urine, which is a hallmark of lead poisoning. This accumulation makes urinary coproporphyrin a valuable diagnostic marker for lead toxicity, as indicated in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers. It primarily affects the respiratory system and does not cause an increase in urinary coproporphyrin levels.

 

Option C. Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust, affecting lung tissue. It does not influence heme synthesis or cause elevated urinary coproporphyrin levels.

 

Option D. Mercury poisoning: Mercury poisoning affects the nervous and renal systems but does not specifically impact the enzymes involved in heme synthesis. It does not lead to increased levels of urinary coproporphyrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead poisoning inhibits enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, resulting in elevated urinary coproporphyrin levels, which is a key diagnostic indicator.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Electron microscopy

 

  • Among the given options, electron microscopy will be the least useful in assessing nasal mucociliary clearance.
  • Electron microscopy -  can detect structural and functional abnormalities of cilia but do not detect any other abnormalities interfering with nasal mucociliary clearance. It is used to visualize the detailed architecture of cilia, which can help identify defects in ciliary structure responsible for impaired mucociliary transport, but it does not measure the actual transport or clearance function.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saccharin Test: This is a straightforward clinical test where a small amount of saccharin is placed on the nasal mucosa, and the time it takes for the subject to taste the sweetness is measured. This time reflects the mucociliary clearance rate.

 

Option C. Charcoal Powder Method: Involves placing a small amount of charcoal powder in the nose and timing how long it takes for it to appear in the pharynx, similarly assessing the clearance capability of the mucociliary apparatus.

 

Option D. Scintigraphy: This nuclear medicine test uses a small amount of radioactive material to track and record mucociliary transport and clearance, providing both functional and anatomical information about the nasal and sinus mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Test for mucociliary clearance is:
    • Saccharin with or without color test in vivo -   Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance.
    • Radioisotope transport testing in vivo
    • Measuring ciliary activity in vitro
    • Nasal nitric oxide -  Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value
    • Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction
    • Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results.
    • The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.

questions.text: An employee who has been diagnosed with tuberculosis is eligible for an extended sickness benefit for? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 2 years

 

Under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act of 1948, employees who are diagnosed with specific long-term illnesses, including tuberculosis, are eligible for an extended sickness benefit. This benefit provides financial support to cover a significant portion of their wages during prolonged periods of illness. The extended sickness benefit offers 80% of the employee's wages for up to 2 years. This provision ensures that employees have continued financial support while they are unable to work due to their medical condition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What are the stages of demographic cycle with same birth rate but variable death rate?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stage 1 + stage 2

 

Explanation: 

 

The demographic transition model consists of five stages, each characterized by different levels of crude birth rates (CBR) and crude death rates (CDR). In stages 1 and 2, the birth rate remains high, while the death rate varies.

 

 

Stage 1 (High Stationary): In this stage, both the CBR (green line) and CDR (red line) are very high, resulting in a relatively stable population size.

 

Stage 2 (Early Expanding): The CBR remains high, but the CDR starts declining due to improvements in medical facilities, more hospitals, and more doctors. This leads to population growth.

 

Other Options:

 

In stage 3 (Late Expanding), the CBR starts declining for the first time due to the introduction of family planning programs, while the CDR continues to decrease. India is currently in this stage.

 

In stage 4 (Low Stationary), both the CBR and CDR are low, resulting in a stable population. This combination does not represent stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.

 

In stage 5 (Declining), the CBR falls below the CDR, leading to population reduction. This combination does not represent stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In stages 1 and 2 of the demographic transition model, the crude birth rate remains high, while the crude death rate is high in stage 1 but starts declining in stage 2, making these the stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB shows resistance to which of the following drugs? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isoniazid and rifampicin

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, which are the two most powerful first-line anti-TB drugs. This resistance makes MDR-TB more difficult and longer to treat than drug-susceptible TB.

 

Isoniazid and rifampicin: These are the cornerstone drugs in the treatment of TB. MDR-TB's resistance to these drugs necessitates the use of second-line medications and a longer, more complex treatment regimen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and fluoroquinolone: While resistance to fluoroquinolones can occur, it characterizes pre-extensively drug-resistant (pre-XDR) TB or extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB, not just MDR-TB.

 

Option B. Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolone resistance typically occurs in more advanced drug-resistant TB cases like pre-XDR and XDR-TB.

 

Option D. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and kanamycin: This option refers to XDR-TB, which includes resistance to at least isoniazid, rifampicin, a fluoroquinolone, and a second-line injectable drug such as kanamycin.

 

Note Old definition of XDR - H and R resistance plus at least one fluoroquinolone resistance plus at least one second line injectable drug resistance like aminoglycosides (amikacin, kanamycin and capreomycin).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most important first-line anti-TB drugs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which screening test will be useful to determine the etiology of this patient's condition? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) D-dimer measurement

 

Explanation:

 

In a bedridden patient presenting with acute onset dyspnea and chest pain, one of the primary differential diagnoses is pulmonary embolism (PE). The patient has already undergone CT pulmonary angiography, which is a gold standard for diagnosing PE.

 

However, for initial screening, D-dimer measurement is very useful:

 

  • D-dimer: This test has a high negative predictive value and high sensitivity. It is a good screening test because if the D-dimer level is negative/ normal, it effectively rules out venous thromboembolism (VTE) such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and PE.
  • Elevated D-dimer levels indicate that further diagnostic imaging, such as CT pulmonary angiography or compression ultrasound, is needed to confirm the presence of VTE, given its poor specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MR Angiogram: This is an imaging modality that can be used for vascular imaging but is not typically used as a screening test for PE.

 

Option B. Echocardiography: This is useful for assessing heart function and diagnosing conditions like heart failure or valvular disease but is not a primary screening test for PE.

 

Option D. Coagulogram: This test assesses blood coagulation status but is not specifically used for screening for PE.

 

Educational Objectives

 

D-dimer measurement is an effective screening test for ruling out pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of VTE.

questions.text: What method is most effective for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence within a given area over time? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Line graph

 

Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot the changes in the incidence of a disease in a given area over time (TREND of any event).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histogram: Is graphical presentation for continuous quantitative data

 

  • Continuous groups are marked on x-axis (abscissa) while frequencies are marked on y-axis (ordinate).

 

 

Option C. Ogive:  Is graph of cumulative relative frequency distribution

 

 

Option D. Stem and leaf plot:  Represents quantitative data in graphical format which helps us visualize the shape of distribution. We are able to represent frequencies for different classes of values.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Line graphs are the most effective method for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence over time, making them ideal for identifying and analyzing trends in epidemiological data.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of measles. Measles virus is a Paramyxovirus which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA (S RNA) virus.

 

The onset of rashes after the development of Koplik spots that are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of premolars, with associated features of coryza, and conjunctivitis is suggestive of measles.

 

Measles: The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This is followed by the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash.

 

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naked ss RNA: Incorrect because the measles virus is enveloped.

 

Option C. Naked ds RNA: No human viruses are known with a naked dsRNA genome.

 

Option D. Enveloped ds RNA: This combination does not apply to human pathogens in the context given (measles virus is ssRNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles virus is characterized as an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus, notable for the unique clinical presentation of Koplik's spots, which precede the characteristic maculopapular rash. This distinguishing feature is essential for the clinical diagnosis of measles.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with diarrhea and weight loss. On examination, the height and weight are lesser than expected. Laboratory investigations were positive for class II HLA-DQ2. Which of the following will you advise the child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gluten-free diet

 

The positive HLA-DQ2 and the presentation of diarrhea and weight loss in a child suggest the possibility of celiac disease. Therefore, the child should be advised to follow a gluten-free diet.

 

Celiac disease is a condition characterized by an abnormal immune response to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. This immune response leads to damage to the small intestine and malabsorption of nutrients, which can result in diarrhea, weight loss, and other symptoms.

 

HLA-DQ2 is a genetic marker that is present in over 90% of individuals with celiac disease. Therefore, a positive test for HLA-DQ2 can suggest the possibility of celiac disease, although a definitive diagnosis requires further testing, such as serologic testing and intestinal biopsy.

 

The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin, a gluten-derived peptide. In the small intestine, gliadin is deamidated by an intestinal enzyme called tissue transglutaminase (tTG), resulting in a more immunogenic form of the protein that is presented to helper T cells. This leads to mucosal inflammation, tissue damage, and other symptoms.

 

Children with celiac disease typically present with diarrhea, weight loss, and growth failure. Other symptoms may include malabsorption, bloating, irregular bowel habits, iron deficiency anemia, osteoporosis, ataxia, and abnormal liver enzymes. Screening for celiac disease is performed by testing for serum antibodies, including tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deaminated anti-gliadin antibodies. The diagnosis is confirmed in patients with positive antibodies by biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum. Microscopic examination of the biopsy sample reveals intraepithelial CD8+ lymphocytes, villous atrophy, and crypt hyperplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fat-free diet: This is not relevant to the management of celiac disease. Fat intake is not directly related to the immune response triggered by gluten.

 

Option B. Lactose-free diet: While some individuals with celiac disease may temporarily develop lactose intolerance due to mucosal damage, a lactose-free diet is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Low carbohydrate diet: This diet is not related to the management of celiac disease. The primary issue is the immune response to gluten, not carbohydrate intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with celiac disease should follow a gluten-free diet to manage symptoms and prevent further intestinal damage.

questions.text: What percentage of increase in FEV1 represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 12%

 

Explanation:

 

To diagnose bronchial asthma, it is essential to demonstrate the reversibility of airway obstruction. This is typically assessed by measuring the increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) after the administration of a bronchodilator.

 

The criteria for significant reversibility in FEV1 are:

 

  • An increase in FEV1 of more than 12% from the baseline.
  • An absolute increase in FEV1 of more than 200 ml.

 

These criteria confirm that the obstruction is reversible, which is a hallmark of asthma.

 

Note - Criterion is used for assessing peak flow rate (PFR) variability is > 20%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A minimum increase of more than 12% in FEV1 after bronchodilator administration is required to demonstrate the reversibility of airway obstruction in bronchial asthma.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, when given with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Astemizole

 

Astemizole is an antihistamine that, when combined with enzyme inhibitors such as erythromycin, can lead to QT prolongation. This prolongation of the QT interval on an electrocardiogram can predispose a person to a dangerous arrhythmia known as Torsades de pointes, which can be potentially life-threatening. Astemizole was withdrawn from many markets due to this severe adverse effect when used in combination with other drugs that inhibit its metabolism.

 

Drugs causing QT prolongation if given with erythromycin:

 

  • Cisapride
  • Astemizole
  • Terfinadine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cetirizine: This is a second-generation antihistamine that does not have significant interactions leading to QT prolongation or Torsades de pointes when combined with erythromycin.

 

Option C. Loratadine: Similar to Cetirizine, Loratadine is another second-generation antihistamine with a better safety profile in terms of cardiac effects. It does not cause QT prolongation or Torsades de pointes in conjunction with erythromycin.

 

Option D. Promethazine: Although promethazine is an older antihistamine that can have sedative effects, it does not have a strong association with QT prolongation or Torsades de pointes when used with erythromycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Astemizole is a drug that, when taken with erythromycin, can lead to QT prolongation and the serious arrhythmia known as Torsades de pointes. This significant adverse effect led to the withdrawal of Astemizole from the market in many countries.

questions.text: According to current recommended dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be of total energy intake: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) < 10%

 

According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be <10% of total energy intake.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be less than 10% of total energy intake.

choices.text: Nil per oral to avoid pancreatic stimulation
Parentral nutrition preferred for 2-3 days over the nil per oral (NPO) approach

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following should be avoided in management of the given condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administration of 5% dextrose 

 

The patient's presentation is suggestive of acute pancreatitis, characterized by severe abdominal pain radiating to the back and elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. The management of acute pancreatitis involves supportive care, including pain management, fluid resuscitation, and nutritional support. 

 

Administering solutions with high glucose content can increase triglyceride levels and potentially exacerbate pancreatitis, especially in a patient who is not eating. This could lead to hyperglycemia, which is why it should be avoided. The fluids preferred are RL or Normal saline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nil per oral (NPO) to avoid pancreatic stimulation: In acute pancreatitis, resting the pancreas by avoiding oral intake is a possible initial management step to prevent further pancreatic enzyme stimulation and reduce pancreatic workload.

 

Option C. Parenteral nutrition preferred for 2-3 days over the NPO approach: Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is generally reserved for patients who cannot meet their nutritional requirements orally or enterally (via the gastrointestinal tract) after several days. The current trend is towards earlier enteral feeding when possible, rather than starting with parenteral nutrition. However, it is not a contra-indication.

 

Option D. Early initiation of oral feedings: If the patient is stable and pain is controlled, early initiation of oral feeding is recommended. This approach has been associated with a shorter hospital stay and lower complication rates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In the management of acute pancreatitis, avoid the administration of high glucose content solutions such as 5% dextrose, as they can exacerbate the condition, and instead focus on pain management, fluid resuscitation, and appropriate nutritional support.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with motor traffic accident with BP 90/60mm Hg. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechia were seen. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. eFAST

 

Explanation:

 

The next step in the evaluation of a trauma patient with the given findings is the Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST). This non-invasive imaging technique is crucial for rapidly identifying free fluid and organ injuries in the abdomen, as well as potential pneumothorax or hemothorax, which are critical in trauma cases. eFAST is used to quickly assess both stable and unstable patients following blunt abdominal trauma, providing immediate information that can dictate further management steps.

 

Details:

 

eFAST Role: This ultrasound examination checks for free intraperitoneal or pericardial fluid and can evaluate the integrity of the pleural spaces.

 

Stability: Despite the patient's low blood pressure, he is neurologically intact (GCS 15/15) and responsive, which allows for an ultrasound examination before more invasive procedures are considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exploratory laparotomy: Generally reserved for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability after eFAST or when eFAST is positive for intra-abdominal injury needing surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Intubation: Might be necessary if respiratory status worsens or if advanced airway management is required, but the patients current stable neurological status does not immediately warrant this.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan): Used after eFAST if the patient remains hemodynamically stable and further detailed evaluation of internal injuries is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of night blindness in pediatric age? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

Night blindness, also known as nyctalopia, is the inability to see well in low light or darkness. The most common cause of night blindness in the pediatric age group is vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the production of rhodopsin, a pigment in the retina that is crucial for vision in low-light conditions.

 

Key Points:

  • Vitamin A deficiency: Leads to inadequate production of rhodopsin, resulting in night blindness.
  • Common causes of vitamin A deficiency: Poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or increased requirements during periods of rapid growth.

 

Symptoms of Vitamin A Deficiency:

  • Night blindness
  • Xerophthalmia (dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea)
  • Bitot's spots (foamy patches on the conjunctiva)
  • Keratomalacia (softening of the cornea)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C deficiency: Causes scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums and perifollicular hemorrhages, but not night blindness.

 

Option B. Congenital glaucoma: A rare condition that can affect vision but does not specifically cause night blindness.

 

Option D. Vitamin E deficiency: Can cause neurological problems and hemolytic anemia but is not typically associated with night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of night blindness in the pediatric age group, emphasizing the importance of adequate intake of vitamin A for maintaining healthy vision, especially in low-light conditions.

questions.text: A female patient presented with a lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma

 

Explanation:

 

The lesion shown in the image exhibits characteristics commonly associated with melanoma, which include:

 

  • Color variability: The lesion displays various shades of color, indicating the uneven distribution of melanin, which is a hallmark of melanoma.
  • Asymmetry: If the lesion is divided into four quadrants, the halves do not match, suggesting asymmetry, another key feature of melanoma.
  • Irregular borders: The borders of the lesion are not smooth or regular but rather irregular and jagged.
  • Diameter: The lesion is likely greater than 6 millimeters in diameter.
  • Evolution: There are changes in the lesion's appearance over time, including alterations in color, shape, and surface.

 

These features correspond to the "ABCDE" criteria used to identify potential melanomas:

 

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variation
  • Diameter greater than 6 mm
  • Evolution over time

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically presents as a papulosquamous lesion rather than a pigmented one. It appears as a scaly, red, crusted nodule or plaque, often on sun-exposed areas.

 

Option C. Basal cell carcinoma: Usually manifests as a translucent nodule, surface telangiectasias and extensive local growth. Basal cell carcinoma lesions often have a rolled border and can ulcerate, forming what is known as a "rodent ulcer." They do not generally present with significant pigmentation or the described irregularities.

 

 

Option D. Seborrhoeic keratosis: Appears as a benign, well-demarcated, pigmented lesion with a "stuck-on" appearance. It typically has a uniform color and texture and lacks the irregular borders, asymmetry, and color variation seen in melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanoma should be suspected in lesions that show asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, diameter greater than 6 mm, and evolution over time. The "ABCDE" criteria are essential in identifying potential melanomas.

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Super supraglottic swallow

 

Super supraglottic swallow is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation but in dysphagia to prevent aspiration of food.

 

The Super-Supraglottic Swallow technique is employed for patients experiencing diminished airway closure. To perform this technique, patients are directed to take a deep breath and tightly hold it while bearing down. They should maintain this breath hold and bear down as they swallow. Immediately after the swallow (before inhaling), they are instructed to cough, followed by a forceful swallow once more (before inhaling). This sequence is aimed at enhancing airway protection during swallowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) is a one-way valve inserted through a tracheoesophageal puncture. Occlusion of the stoma shunts the exhaled air through the TEP into the esophagus producing vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter resulting in phonation.

Option B. Esophageal speech is phonation produced by vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter.

 

Option C. Polite yawning also called nasal airflow-inducing maneuver is indicated for olfaction rehabilitation post laryngectomy. This maneuver induces a negative pressure in the oral cavity and oropharynx, which generates a nasal airflow, enabling odorous substances to reach the olfactory epithelium again.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Super supraglottic swallow technique is crucial for enhancing airway protection in dysphagia management but is not utilized in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation, where the focus is primarily on restoring voice and smell functions through other specialized techniques.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition 352, 353; Scott Brown 7th edition, Volume 2, Page No. 2090

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chest pain, dyspnea increasing on lying down and relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled and her lungs are clear. CXR given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cardiac Tamponade

 

The patient's presentation and findings are indicative of cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade occurs when fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart and impairing its ability to pump effectively. This condition can result from various causes, including pericarditis, malignancy, trauma, or post-myocardial infarction.

 

Key features supporting cardiac tamponade:

 

  1. Chest pain and dyspnea: These symptoms can worsen when lying down and improve when sitting up, a condition known as orthopnea.
  2. Muffled heart sounds: Due to the fluid in the pericardial sac, the heart sounds are dampened.
  3. Clear lungs: This helps differentiate from pulmonary causes of dyspnea.
  4. Enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR: The chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, indicative of pericardial effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Pulmonary edema: This condition typically presents with bilateral crackles on lung auscultation and possibly a history of heart failure. The chest X-ray would show features like Kerley B lines, pleural effusions, or alveolar edema, which are absent in this case.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary embolism: This can present with dyspnea and chest pain, but the ECG findings and clear lung fields on auscultation are less supportive. Additionally, acute pulmonary embolism typically does not cause an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

 

Option C. Acute MI (Myocardial Infarction): While acute MI can present with chest pain and dyspnea, it usually does not result in muffled heart sounds or an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Acute MI would more likely present with changes on ECG and possibly signs of heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade presents with symptoms of chest pain and dyspnea that worsen when lying down and improve when sitting up, muffled heart sounds, clear lung fields, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition from the given graph. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive

 

The graph shown is a Lineweaver-Burk plot, which is a double reciprocal plot commonly used to illustrate enzyme kinetics. In this plot, the x-axis represents the reciprocal of the substrate concentration (1/[S]), and the y-axis represents the reciprocal of the reaction velocity (1/V). The graph is particularly useful in distinguishing different types of enzyme inhibition.

 

In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This type of inhibition is characterized by an increase in the apparent Km (Michaelis constant), which is reflected as a change in the slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot. However, the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged because the effect of the inhibitor can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration.

 

In the Lineweaver-Burk plot, this is depicted as the two lines (with and without inhibitor) crossing at the y-axis. The y-intercept remains the same (indicating unchanged Vmax), but the slope changes due to the increase in apparent Km, which shifts the x-intercept closer to the origin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-competitive: In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, not the active site. This binding reduces the overall number of active enzyme molecules, thereby decreasing Vmax without affecting Km. In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, this results in lines that intersect on the x-axis, not the y-axis.

 

 

Option C. Un-competitive: Un-competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the free enzyme. This results in parallel lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, as both Km and Vmax decrease.

 

 

Option D. Allosteric: Allosteric inhibition involves the binding of an inhibitor to a site other than the active site, leading to changes in enzyme activity. This type of inhibition is more complex and isn't typically represented by a Lineweaver-Burk plot in the same way competitive, non-competitive, or un-competitive inhibitions are.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In competitive inhibition, the Lineweaver-Burk plot shows lines that cross at the y-axis, indicating that Vmax remains unchanged while Km increases due to the competition between the inhibitor and the substrate for the enzyme's active site.
